These days it seems that cybersecurity and the fear of hackers is at an all time high. This fear has caused many official institutions to revert to old techniques that don't require high tech equipment. For example, a couple of years ago local news outlets reported that a security force that guards high-ranking Russian officials reverted to using typewriters after revelations about U.S. digital spying capabilities. It is now being revealed that the U.S. Navy is rebuilding a celestial navigation training program for all enlisted ranks. 
The Naval Academy cut celestial navigation training nearly 20 years ago, and the practice ended at large in about 2006. The Navy was mostly focusing on computer navigation, simply because it was much easier and much more efficient. However, due to the growing fear of cyber attacks, the Navy is bringing back celestial navigation training. 
Bringing back this old technique is a fail-safe for the U.S. Navy. Computers will obviously not be taken out of the equation; rather they are looking for ways to integrate both the old and the new practices. Being knowledgeable on celestial navigation is important for the Navy because computers are always vulnerable to hackers and to breaking down. While computer navigation can still be the primary practice, celestial navigation is a great back up if/when computers fail or fall victim to cyber attacks.
